books.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy

chapters.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:1
verses.text: Epistles on the Arian Heresy: I.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:2
verses.text: â€”To Alexander, Bishop of the City of Constantinople.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:3
verses.text: To the most reverend and like-minded brother, Alexander, Alexander sends greeting in the Lord:.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:4
verses.text: The ambitious and avaricious will of wicked men is always wont to lay snares against those churches which seem greater, by various pretexts attacking the ecclesiastical piety of such.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:5
verses.text: For incited by the devil who works in them, to the lust of that which is set before them, and throwing away all religious scruples, they trample under foot the fear of the judgment of God.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:6
verses.text: Concerning which things, I who suffer, have thought it necessary to show to your piety, in order that you may be aware of such men, lest any of them presume to set foot in your dioceses, whether by themselves or by others; for these sorcerers know how to use hypocrisy to carry out their fraud; and to employ letters composed and dressed out with lies, which are able to deceive a man who is intent upon a simple and sincere faith.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:7
verses.text: Arius, therefore, and Achilles, having lately entered into a conspiracy, emulating the ambition of Colluthus, have turned out far worse than he.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:8
verses.text: For Colluthus, indeed, who reprehends these very men, found some pretext for his evil purpose; but these, beholding his battering of Christ, endured no longer to be subject to the Church; but building for themselves dens of thieves, they hold their assemblies in them unceasingly, night and day directing their calumnies against Christ and against us.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:9
verses.text: For since they call in question all pious and apostolical doctrine, after the manner of the Jews, they have constructed a workshop for contending against Christ, denying the Godhead of our Saviour, and preaching that He is only the equal of all others.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:10
verses.text: And having collected all the passages which speak of His plan of salvation and His humiliation for our sakes, they endeavour from these to collect the preaching of their impiety, ignoring altogether the passages in which His eternal Godhead and unutterable glory with the Father is set forth.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:11
verses.text: Since, therefore, they back up the impious opinion concerning Christ, which is held by the Jews and Greeks, in every possible way they strive to gain their approval; busying themselves about all those things which they are wont to deride in us, and daily stirring up against us seditions and persecutions.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:12
verses.text: And now, indeed, they drag us before the tribunals of the judges, by intercourse with silly and disorderly women, whom they have led into error; at another time they cast opprobrium and infamy upon the Christian religion, their young maidens disgracefully wandering about every village and street.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:13
verses.text: Nay, even Christ's indivisible tunic, which His executioners were unwilling to divide, these wretches have dared to rend.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:14
verses.text: And we, indeed, though we discovered rather late, on account of their concealment, their manner of life, and their unholy attempts, by the common suffrage of all have cast them forth from the congregation of the Church which adores the Godhead of Christ.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:15
verses.text: But they, running hither and thither against us, have begun to betake themselves to our colleagues who are of the same mind with us; in appearance, indeed, pretending to seek for peace and concord, but in reality seeking to draw over some of them by fair words to their own diseases, asking long wordy letters from them, in order that reading these to the men whom they have deceived, they may make them impenitent in the errors into which they have fallen, and obdurate in impiety, as if they had bishops thinking the same thing and siding with them.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:16
verses.text: Moreover, the things which amongst us they have wrongly taught and done, and on account of which they have been expelled by us, they do not at all confess to them, but they either pass them over in silence, or throwing a veil over them, by feigned words and writings they deceive them.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:17
verses.text: Concealing, therefore, their pestilent doctrine by their specious and flattering discourse, they circumvent the more simple-minded and such as are open to fraud, nor do they spare in the meanwhile to traduce our piety to all.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:18
verses.text: Hence it comes to pass that some, subscribing their letters, receive them into the Church, although in my opinion the greatest guilt lies upon those ministers who venture to do this; because not only does the apostolic rule not allow of it, but the working of the devil in these men against Christ is by this means more strongly kindled.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:19
verses.text: Wherefore without delay, brethren beloved, I have stirred myself up to show you the faithlessness of these men who say that there was a time when the Son of God was not; and that He who was not before, came into existence afterwards, becoming such, when at length He was made, even as every man is wont to be born.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:20
verses.text: For, they say, God made all things from things which are not, comprehending even the Son of God in the creation of all things rational and irrational.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:21
verses.text: To which things they add as a consequence, that He is of mutable nature, and capable both of virtue and vice.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:22
verses.text: And this hypothesis being once assumed, that He is "from things which are not," they overturn the sacred writings concerning His eternity, which signify the immutability and the Godhead of Wisdom and the Word, which are Christ.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:23
verses.text: We, therefore, say these wicked men, can also be the sons of God even as He.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:24
verses.text: For it is written, "I have nourished and brought up children".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:25
verses.text: But when what follows was objected to them, "and they have rebelled against me," which indeed is not applicable to the nature of the Saviour, who is of an immutable nature; they, throwing off all religious reverence, say that God, since He foreknew and had foreseen that His Son would not rebel against Him, chose Him from all.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:26
verses.text: For He did not choose Him as having by nature anything specially beyond His other sons, for no one is by nature a son of God, as they say; neither as having any peculiar property of His own; but God chose Him who was of a mutable nature, on account of the carefulness of His manners and His practice, which in no way turned to that which is evil; so that, if Paul and Peter had striven for this, there would have been no difference between their sonship and His.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:27
verses.text: And to confirm this insane doctrine, playing with Holy Scripture, they bring forward what is said in the Psalms respecting Christ: "Thou lovest righteousness, and hatest wickedness: therefore God, Thy God, hath anointed Thee with the oil of gladness above Thy fellows".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:28
verses.text: But that the Son of God was not made "from things which are not," and that there was no "time when He was not," the evangelist John sufficiently shows, when he thus writes concerning Him: "The only-begotten Son, who is in the bosom of the Father".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:29
verses.text: For since that divine teacher intended to show that the Father and the Son are two things inseparable the one from the other, he spoke of Him as being in the bosom of the Father.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:30
verses.text: Now that also the Word of God is not comprehended in the number of things that were created "from things which are not," the same John says, "All things were made by Him".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:31
verses.text: For he set forth His proper personality, saying, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:32
verses.text: All things were made by Him; and without Him was not anything made that was made".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:33
verses.text: For if all things were made by Him, how comes it that He who gave to the things which are made their existence, at one time Himself was not.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:34
verses.text: For the Word which makes is not to be defined as being of the same nature with the things which are made; since He indeed was in the beginning, and all things were made by Him, and fashioned "from things which are not".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:35
verses.text: Moreover, that which is seems to be contrary to and far removed from those things which are made "from things which are not".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:36
verses.text: For that indeed shows that there is no interval between the Father and the Son, since not even in thought can the mind imagine any distance between them.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:37
verses.text: But that the world was created "from things which are not," indicates a more recent and later origin of substance, since the universe receives an essence of this sort from the Father by the Son.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:38
verses.text: When, therefore, the most pious John contemplated the essence of the divine Word at a very great distance, and as placed beyond all conception of those things that are begotten, he thought it not meet to speak of His generation and creation; not daring to designate the Creator in the same terms as the things that are made.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:39
verses.text: Not that the Word is unbegotten, for the Father alone is unbegotten, but because the inexplicable subsistence of the only-begotten Son transcends the acute comprehension of the evangelists, and perhaps also of angels.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:40
verses.text: Wherefore I do not think that he is to be reckoned amongst the pious who presumes to inquire into anything beyond these things, not listening to this saying: "Seek not out the things that are too hard for thee, neither search the things that are above thy strength".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:41
verses.text: For if the knowledge of many other things that are incomparably inferior to this, are hidden from human comprehension, such as in the apostle Paul, "Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love Him".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:42
verses.text: As also God said to Abraham, that "he could not number the stars;" and that passage, "Who can number the sand of the sea, and the drops of rain".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:43
verses.text: How shall any one be able to investigate too curiously the subsistence of the divine Word, unless he be smitten with frenzy? Concerning which the Spirit of prophecy says, "Who shall declare his generation?" And our Saviour Himself, who blesses the pillars of all things in the world, sought to unburden them of the knowledge of these things, saying that to comprehend this was quite beyond their nature, and that to the Father alone belonged the knowledge of this most divine mystery.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:44
verses.text: "For no man," says He, "knoweth the Son, but the Father: neither knoweth any man the Father, save the Son".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:45
verses.text: Of this thing also I think that the Father spoke, in the words, "My secret is to Me and Mine".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:46
verses.text: Now that it is an insane thing to think that the Son was made from things which are not, and was in being in time, the expression, "from things which are not," itself shows, although these stupid men understand not the insanity of their own words.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:47
verses.text: For the expression, "was not," ought either to be reckoned in time, or in some place of an age.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:48
verses.text: But if it be true that "all things were made by Him," it is established that both every age and time and all space, and that "when" in which the "was not" is found, was made by Him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:49
verses.text: And is it not absurd that He who fashioned the times and the ages and the seasons, in which that "was not" is mixed up, to say of Him, that He at some time was not? For it is devoid of sense, and a mark of great ignorance, to affirm that He who is the cause of everything is posterior to the origin of that thing.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:50
verses.text: For according to them, the space of time in which they say that the Son had not yet been made by the Father, preceded the wisdom of God that fashioned all things, and the Scripture speaks falsely according to them, which calls Him "the First-born of every creature".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:51
verses.text: Conformable to which, that which the majestically-speaking Paul says of Him: "Whom He hath appointed heir of all things.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:52
verses.text: By whom also He made the worlds.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:53
verses.text: But by Him also were all things created that are in heaven, and that are in earth, visible and invisible, whether they be thrones or dominions, or principalities, or powers; all things were created by Him, and for Him; and He is before all things".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:54
verses.text: Wherefore, since it appears that this hypothesis of a creation from things which are not is most impious, it is necessary to say that the Father is always the Father.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:55
verses.text: But He is the Father, since the Son is always with Him, on account of whom He is called the Father.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:56
verses.text: Wherefore, since the Son is always with Him, the Father is always perfect, being destitute of nothing as regards good; who, not in time, nor after an interval, nor from things which are not, hath begotten His only-begotten Son.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:57
verses.text: How, then, is it not impious to say, that the wisdom of God once was not which speaks thus concerning itself: "I was with Him forming all things; I was His delight;" or that the power of God once did not exist; or that His Word was at any time mutilated; or that other things were ever wanting from which the Son is known and the Father expressed? For he who denies that the brightness of the glory existed, takes away also the primitive light of which it is the brightness.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:58
verses.text: And if the image of God was not always, it is clear also that He was not always, of which it is the image.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:59
verses.text: Moreover, in saying that the character of the subsistence of God was not, He also is done away with who is perfectly expressed by it.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:60
verses.text: Hence one may see that the Sonship of our Saviour has nothing at all in common with the sonship of the rest.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:61
verses.text: For just as it has been shown that His inexplicable subsistence excels by an incomparable excellence all other things to which He has given existence, so also His Sonship, which is according to the nature of the Godhead of the Father, transcends, by an ineffable excellence, the sonship of those who have been adopted by Him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:62
verses.text: For He, indeed, is of an immutable nature, every way perfect, and wanting in nothing; but these since they are either way subject to change, stand in need of help from Him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:63
verses.text: For what progress can the wisdom of God make? What increase can the truth itself and God the Word receive? In what respect can the life and the true light be made better? And if this be so, how much more unnatural is it that wisdom should ever be capable of folly; that the power of God should be conjoined with infirmity; that reason should be obscured by unreason; or that darkness should be mixed up with the true light? And the apostle says, on this place, "What communion hath light with darkness? and what concord hath Christ with Belial?" And Solomon says, that it is not possible that it should come to pass that a man should comprehend with his understanding "the way of a serpent upon a rock," which is Christ, according to the opinion of Paul.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:64
verses.text: But men and angels, who are His creatures, have received His blessing that they might make progress, exercising themselves in virtues and in the commandments of the law, so as not to sin.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:65
verses.text: Wherefore our Lord, since He is by nature the Son of the Father, is by all adored.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:66
verses.text: But these, laying aside the spirit of bondage, when by brave deeds and by progress they have received the spirit of adoption, being blessed by Him who is the Son by nature, are made sons by adoption.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:67
verses.text: And His proper and peculiar, natural and excellent Sonship, St.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:68
verses.text: Paul has declared, who thus speaks of God: "Who spared not His own Son, but for us," who were not His natural sons, "delivered Him up".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:69
verses.text: For to distinguish Him from those who are not properly sons, He said that He was His own Son.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:70
verses.text: And in the Gospel we read: "This is My beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:71
verses.text: Moreover, in the Psalms the Saviour says: "The Lord hath said unto Me, Thou art my Son".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:72
verses.text: Where, showing that He is the true and genuine Son, He signifies that there are no other genuine sons besides Himself.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:73
verses.text: And what, too, is the meaning of this: "From the womb before the morning I begat thee"? Does He not plainly indicate the natural sonship of paternal bringing forth, which he obtained not by the careful framing of His manners, not by the exercise of and increase in virtue, but by property of nature? Wherefore, the only-begotten Son of the Father, indeed, possesses an indefectible Sonship; but the adoption of rational sons belongs not to them by nature, but is prepared for them by the probity of their life, and by the free gift of God.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:74
verses.text: And it is mutable as the Scripture recognises: "For when the sons of God saw the daughters of men, they took them wives," etc.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:75
verses.text: And in another place: "I have nourished and brought up children, but they have rebelled against Me," as we find God speaking by the prophet Isaiah.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:76
verses.text: And though I could say much more, brethren beloved, I purposely omit to do so, as deeming it to be burdensome at great length to call these things to the remembrance of teachers who are of the same mind with myself.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:77
verses.text: For ye yourselves are taught of God, nor are ye ignorant that this doctrine, which hath lately raised its head against the piety of the Church, is that of Ebion and Artemas; nor is it aught else but an imitation of Paul of Samosata, bishop of Antioch, who, by the judgment and counsel of all the bishops, and in every place, was separated from the Church.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:78
verses.text: To whom Lucian succeeding, remained for many years separate from the communion of three bishops.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:79
verses.text: And now lately having drained the dregs of their impiety, there have arisen amongst us those who teach this doctrine of a creation from things which are not, their hidden sprouts, Arius and Achilles, and the gathering of those who join in their wickedness.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:80
verses.text: And three bishops in Syria, having been, in some manner, consecrated on account of their agreement with them, incite them to worse things.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:81
verses.text: But let the judgment concerning these be reserved for your trial.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:82
verses.text: For they, retaining in their memory the words which came to be used with respect to His saving Passion, and abasement, and examination, and what they call His poverty, and in short of all those things to which the Saviour submitted for our sakes, bring them forward to refute His supreme and eternal Godhead.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:83
verses.text: But of those words which signify His natural glory and nobility, and abiding with the Father, they have become unmindful.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:84
verses.text: Such as this: "I and My Father are one," which indeed the Lord says, not as proclaiming Himself to be the Father, nor to demonstrate that two persons are one; but that the Son of the Father most exactly preserves the expressed likeness of the Father, inasmuch as He has by nature impressed upon Him His similitude in every respect, and is the image of the Father in no way discrepant, and the expressed figure of the primitive exemplar.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:85
verses.text: Whence, also, to Philip, who then was desirous to see Him, the Lord shows this abundantly.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:86
verses.text: For when he said, "Show us the Father," He answered: "He that hath seen Me, hath seen the Father," since the Father was Himself seen through the spotless and living mirror of the divine image.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:87
verses.text: Similar to which is what the saints say in the Psalms: "In Thy light shall we see light".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:88
verses.text: Wherefore he that honoureth the Son, honoureth the Father also;" and with reason, for every impious word which they dare to speak against the Son, has reference to the Father.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:89
verses.text: But after these things, brethren beloved, what is there wonderful in that which I am about to write, if I shall set forth the false calumnies against me and our most pious laity? For those who have set themselves in array against the Godhead of Christ, do not scruple to utter their ungrateful ravings against us.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:90
verses.text: Who will not either that any of the ancients should be compared with them, or suffer that any of those whom, from our earliest years, we have used as instructors should be placed on a level with them.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:91
verses.text: Nay, and they do not think that any of all those who are now our colleagues, has attained even to a moderate amount of wisdom; boasting themselves to be the only men who are wise and divested of worldly possessions, the sole discoverers of dogmas, and that to them alone are those things revealed which have never before come into the mind of any other under the sun.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:92
verses.text: Oh, the impious arrogance! Oh, the immeasurable madness! Oh, the vainglory befitting those that are crazed! Oh, the pride of Satan which has taken root in their unholy souls.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:93
verses.text: The religious perspicuity of the ancient Scriptures caused them no shame, nor did the consentient doctrine of our colleagues concerning Christ keep in check their audacity against Him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:94
verses.text: Their impiety not even the demons will bear, who are ever on the watch for a blasphemous word uttered against the Son.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:95
verses.text: And let these things be now urged according to our power against those who, with respect to matter which they know nothing of, have, as it were, rolled in the dust against Christ, and have taken in hand to calumniate our piety towards Him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:96
verses.text: For those inventors of stupid fables say, that we who turn away with aversion from the impious and unscriptural blasphemy against Christ, of those who speak of His coming from the things which are not assert, that there are two unbegottens.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:97
verses.text: For they ignorantly affirm that one of two things must necessarily be said, either that He is from things which are not, or that there are two unbegottens; nor do those ignorant men know how great is the difference between the unbegotten Father, and the things which were by Him created from things which are not, as well the rational as the irrational.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:98
verses.text: Between which two, as holding the middle place, the only begotten nature of God, the Word by which the Father formed all things out of nothing, was begotten of the true Father Himself.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:99
verses.text: As in a certain place the Lord Himself testified, saying, "Every one that loveth Him that begat, loveth Him also that is begotten of Him".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:100
verses.text: Concerning whom we thus believe, even as the Apostolic Church believes.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:101
verses.text: In one Father unbegotten, who has from no one the cause of His being, who is unchangeable and immutable, who is always the same, and admits of no increase or diminution; who gave to us the Law, the prophets, and the Gospels; who is Lord of the patriarchs and apostles, and all the saints.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:102
verses.text: And in one Lord Jesus Christ, the only-begotten Son of God; not begotten of things which are not, but of Him who is the Father; not in a corporeal manner, by excision or division as Sabellius and Valentinus thought, but in a certain inexplicable and unspeakable manner, according to the words of the prophet cited above: "Who shall declare His generation?" Since that His subsistence no nature which is begotten can investigate, even as the Father can be investigated by none; because that the nature of rational beings cannot receive the knowledge of His divine generation by the Father.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:103
verses.text: But men who are moved by the Spirit of truth, have no need to learn these things from me, for in our ears are sounding the words before uttered by Christ on this very thing, "No man knoweth the Father, save the Son; and no man knoweth who the Son is, save the Father".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:104
verses.text: That He is equally with the Father unchangeable and immutable, wanting in nothing, and the perfect Son, and like to the Father, we have learnt; in this alone is He inferior to the Father, that He is not unbegotten.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:105
verses.text: For He is the very exact image of the Father, and in nothing differing from Him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:106
verses.text: For it is clear that He is the image fully containing all things by which the greatest similitude is declared, as the Lord Himself hath taught us, when He says, "My Father is greater than I".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:107
verses.text: And according to this we believe that the Son is of the Father, always existing.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:108
verses.text: "For He is the brightness of His glory, the express image of His Father's person".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:109
verses.text: But let no one take that word always so as to raise suspicion that He is unbegotten, as they imagine who have their senses blinded.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:110
verses.text: For neither are the words, "He was," or "always," or "before all worlds," equivalent to unbegotten.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:111
verses.text: But neither can the human mind employ any other word to signify unbegotten.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:112
verses.text: And thus I think that you understand it, and I trust to your right purpose in all things, since these words do not at all signify unbegotten.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:113
verses.text: For these words seem to denote simply a lengthening out of time, but the Godhead, and as it were the antiquity of the only-begotten, they cannot worthily signify; but they have been employed by holy men, whilst each, according to his capacity, seeks to express this mystery, asking indulgence from the hearers, and pleading a reasonable excuse, in saying, Thus far have we attained.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:114
verses.text: But if there be any who are expecting from mortal lips some word which exceeds human capacity, saying that those things have been done away which are known in part, it is manifest that the words, "He was," and "always," and "before all ages," come far short of what they hoped.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:115
verses.text: And whatever word shall be employed is not equivalent to unbegotten.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:116
verses.text: Therefore to the unbegotten Father, indeed, we ought to preserve His proper dignity, in confessing that no one is the cause of His being; but to the Son must be allotted His fitting honour, in assigning to Him, as we have said, a generation from the Father without beginning, and allotting adoration to Him, so as only piously and properly to use the words, "He was," and "always," and "before all worlds," with respect to Him; by no means rejecting His Godhead, but ascribing to Him a similitude which exactly answers in every respect to the Image and Exemplar of the Father.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:117
verses.text: But we must say that to the Father alone belongs the property of being unbegotten, for the Saviour Himself said, "My Father is greater than I".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:118
verses.text: And besides the pious opinion concerning the Father and the Son, we confess to one Holy Spirit, as the divine Scriptures teach us; who hath inaugurated both the holy men of the Old Testament, and the divine teachers of that which is called the New.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:119
verses.text: And besides, also, one only Catholic and Apostolic Church, which can never be destroyed, though all the world should seek to make war with it; but it is victorious over every most impious revolt of the heretics who rise up against it.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:120
verses.text: For her Goodman hath confirmed our minds by saying, "Be of good cheer, I have overcome the world".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:121
verses.text: After this we know of the resurrection of the dead, the first-fruits of which was our Lord Jesus Christ, who in very deed, and not in appearance merely, carried a body, of Mary Mother of God, who in the end of the world came to the human race to put away sin, was crucified and died, and yet did He not thus perceive any detriment to His divinity, being raised from the dead, taken up into heaven, seated at the right hand of majesty.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:122
verses.text: These things in part have I written in this epistle, thinking it burdensome to write out each accurately, even as I said before, because they escape not your religious diligence.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:123
verses.text: Thus do we teach, thus do we preach.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:124
verses.text: These are the apostolic doctrines of the Church, for which also we die, esteeming those but little who would compel us to forswear them, even if they would force us by tortures, and not casting away our hope in them.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:125
verses.text: To these Arius and Achilles opposing themselves, and those who with them are the enemies of the truth, have been expelled from the Church, as being aliens from our holy doctrine, according to the blessed Paul, who says, "If any man preach any other gospel unto you than that ye have received, let him be accursed; even though he feign himself an angel from heaven".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:126
verses.text: And also, "If any man teach otherwise, and consent not to the wholesome words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and to the doctrine which is according to godliness; he is proud, knowing nothing," and so forth.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:127
verses.text: These, therefore, who have been anathematized by the brotherhood, let no one of you receive, nor admit of those things which are either said or written by them.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:128
verses.text: For these seducers do always lie, nor will they ever speak the truth.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:129
verses.text: They go about the cities, attempting nothing else but that under the mark of friendship and the name of peace, by their hypocrisy and blandishments, they may give and receive letters, to deceive by means of these a few "silly women, and laden with sins, who have been led captive by them," and so forth.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:130
verses.text: These men, therefore, who have dared such things against Christ; who have partly in public derided the Christian religion; partly seek to traduce and inform against its professors before the judgment-seats; who in a time of peace, as far as in them lies, have stirred up a persecution against us; who have enervated the ineffable mystery of Christ's generation; from these, I say, beloved and like-minded brethren, turning away in aversion, give your suffrages with us against their mad daring; even as our colleagues have done, who being moved with indignation, have both written to us letters against these men, and have subscribed our letter.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:131
verses.text: Which also I have sent unto you by my son Apion the deacon, being some of them from the whole of Egypt and the Thebaid, some from Libya and Pentapolis.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:132
verses.text: There are others also from Syria, Lycia, Pamphylia, Asia, Cappadocia, and the other neighbouring provinces.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:133
verses.text: After the example of which I trust also that I shall receive letters from you.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:134
verses.text: For though I have prepared many helps towards curing those who have suffered injury, this is the especial remedy that has been devised for healing the multitudes that have been deceived by them, that they may comply with the general consent of our colleagues, and thus hasten to return to repentance.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:135
verses.text: Salute one another, together with the brethren who are with you.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 1:136
verses.text: I pray that ye may be strong in the Lord, beloved, and that I may profit by your love towards Christ.

chapters.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:1
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:2
verses.text: â€”Epistle Catholic.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:3
verses.text: To our beloved and most reverend fellow-ministers of the Catholic Church in every place, Alexander sends greeting in the Lord:.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:4
verses.text: Since the body of the Catholic Church is one, and it is commanded in Holy Scripture that we should keep the bond of unanimity and peace, it follows that we should write and signify to one another the things which are done by each of us; that whether one member suffer or rejoice we may all either suffer or rejoice with one another.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:5
verses.text: In our diocese, then, not so long ago, there have gone forth lawless men, and adversaries of Christ, teaching men to apostatize; which thing, with good right, one might suspect and call the precursor of Antichrist.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:6
verses.text: I indeed wished to cover the matter up in silence, that so perhaps the evil might spend itself in the leaders of the heresy alone, and that it might not spread to other places and defile the ears of any of the more simple-minded.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:7
verses.text: But since Eusebius, the present bishop of Nicomedia, imagining that with him rest all ecclesiastical matters, because, having left Berytus and cast his eyes upon the church of the Nicomedians, and no punishment has been inflicted upon him, he is set over these apostates, and has undertaken to write everywhere, commending them, if by any means he may draw aside some who are ignorant to this most disgraceful and Antichristian heresy; it became necessary for me, as knowing what is written in the law, no longer to remain silent, but to announce to you all, that you may know both those who have become apostates, and also the wretched words of their heresy; and if Eusebius write, not to give heed to him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:8
verses.text: For he, desiring by their assistance to renew that ancient wickedness of his mind, with respect to which he has for a time been silent, pretends that he is writing in their behalf, but he proves by his deed that he is exerting himself to do this on his own account.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:9
verses.text: Now the apostates from the Church are these: Arius, Achilles, Aithales, Carpones, the other Arius, Sarmates, who were formerly priests; Euzoius, Lucius, Julius, Menas, Helladius, and Gaius, formerly deacons; and with them Secundus and Theonas, who were once called bishops.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:10
verses.text: And the words invented by them, and spoken contrary to the mind of Scripture, are as follows:â€”  "God was not always the Father; but there was a time when God was not the Father.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:11
verses.text: The Word of God was not always, but was made 'from things that are not;' for He who is God fashioned the non-existing from the non-existing; wherefore there was a time when He was not.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:12
verses.text: For the Son is a thing created, and a thing made: nor is He like to the Father in substance; nor is He the true and natural Word of the Father; nor is He His true Wisdom; but He is one of the things fashioned and made.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:13
verses.text: And He is called, by a misapplication of the terms, the Word and Wisdom, since He is Himself made by the proper Word of God, and by that wisdom which is in God, in which, as God made all other things, so also did He make Him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:14
verses.text: Wherefore, He is by His very nature changeable and mutable, equally with other rational beings.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:15
verses.text: The Word, too, is alien and separate from the substance of God.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:16
verses.text: The father also is ineffable to the Son; for neither does the Word perfectly and accurately know the Father, neither can He perfectly see Him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:17
verses.text: For neither does the Son indeed know His own substance as it is.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:18
verses.text: Since He for our sakes was made, that by Him as by an instrument God might create us; nor would He have existed had not God wished to make us.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:19
verses.text: Some one asked of them whether the Son of God could change even as the devil changed; and they feared not to answer that He can; for since He was made and created, He is of mutable nature".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:20
verses.text: Since those about Arius speak these things and shamelessly maintain them, we, coming together with the Bishops of Egypt and the Libyas, nearly a hundred in number, have anathematized them, together with their followers.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:21
verses.text: But those about Eusebius have received them, earnestly endeavouring to mix up falsehood with truth, impiety with piety.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:22
verses.text: But they will not prevail; for the truth prevails, and there is no communion betwixt light and darkness, no concord between Christ and Belial.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:23
verses.text: For who ever heard such things? or who, now hearing them, is not astonished, and does not stop his ears that the pollution of these words should not touch them? Who that hears John saying, "In the beginning was the Word," does not condemn those who say there was a time when He was not? Who that hears these words of the Gospel, "the only-begotten Son;" and, "by Him were all things made," will not hate those who declare He is one of the things made? For how can He be one of the things made by Him? or how shall He be the only-begotten who, as they say, is reckoned with all the rest, if indeed He is a thing made and created? And how can He be made of things which are not, when the Father says, "My heart belched forth a good Word;" and, "From the womb, before the morning have I begotten Thee?" Or how is He unlike to the substance of the Father, who is the perfect image and brightness of the Father, and who says, "He that hath seen Me hath seen the Father?" And how, if the Son is the Word or Wisdom and Reason of God, was there a time when He was not? It is all one as if they said, that there was a time when God was without reason and wisdom.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:24
verses.text: How, also, can He be changeable and mutable, who says indeed by Himself: "I am in the Father, and the Father in Me," and, "I and My Father are one;" and by the prophet, "I am the Lord, I change not?" For even though one saying may refer to the Father Himself, yet it would now be more aptly spoken of the Word, because when He became man, He changed not; but, as says the apostle, "Jesus Christ, the same yesterday, today, and for ever".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:25
verses.text: Who hath induced them to say, that for our sakes He was made; although Paul says, "for whom are all things, and by whom are all things?".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:26
verses.text: Now concerning their blasphemous assertion who say that the Son does not perfectly know the Father, we need not wonder: for having once purposed in their mind to wage war against Christ, they impugn also these words of His, "As the Father knoweth Me, even so know I the Father".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:27
verses.text: Wherefore, if the Father only in part knoweth the Son, then it is evident that the Son doth not perfectly know the Father.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:28
verses.text: But if it be wicked thus to speak, and if the Father perfectly knows the Son, it is plain that, even as the Father knoweth His own Word, so also the Word knoweth His own Father, of whom He is the Word.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:29
verses.text: By saying these things, and by unfolding the divine Scriptures, we have often refuted them.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:30
verses.text: But they, chameleon-like, changing their sentiments, endeavour to claim for themselves that saying: "When the wicked cometh, then cometh contempt".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:31
verses.text: Before them, indeed, many heresies existed, which, having dared more than was right, have fallen into madness.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:32
verses.text: But these by all their words have attempted to do away with the Godhead of Christ, have made those seem righteous, since they have come nearer to Antichrist.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:33
verses.text: Wherefore they have been excommunicated and anathematized by the Church.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:34
verses.text: And indeed, although we grieve at the destruction of these men, especially that after having once learned the doctrine of the Church, they have now gone back; yet we do not wonder at it; for this very thing Hymenaeus and Philetus suffered, and before them Judas, who, though he followed the Saviour, afterwards became a traitor and an apostate.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:35
verses.text: Moreover, concerning these very men, warnings are not wanting to us, for the Lord foretold: "Take heed that ye be not deceived: for many shall come in My Name, saying, I am Christ; and the time draweth near: go ye not therefore after them".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:36
verses.text: Paul, too, having learnt these things from the Saviour, wrote, "In the latter times some shall depart from the faith, giving heed to seducing spirits, and doctrines of devils which turn away from the truth".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:37
verses.text: Since, therefore, our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ has thus Himself exhorted us, and by His apostle hath signified such things to us; we, who have heard their impiety with our own ears, have consistently anathematized such men, as I have already said, and have declared them to be aliens from the Catholic Church and faith, and we have made known the thing, beloved and most honoured fellow-ministers, to your piety, that you should not receive any of them, should they venture rashly to come unto you, and that you should not trust Eusebius or any one else who writes concerning them.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:38
verses.text: For it becomes us as Christians to turn with aversion from all who speak or think against Christ, as the adversaries of God and the destroyers of souls, and "not even to wish them Godspeed, lest at any time we become partakers of their evil deeds," as the blessed John enjoins.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 2:39
verses.text: Salute the brethren who are with you.
