chapters.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 3

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 3:1
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 3:2
verses.text: â€”Epistle.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 3:3
verses.text: Alexander, to the priests and deacons, Alexandria and Mareotis, being present to them present, brethren beloved in the Lord, sends greeting:  Although you have been forward to subscribe the letters that I sent to those about Arius, urging them to abjure their impiety, and to obey the wholesome and Catholic faith; and in this manner have shown your orthodox purpose, and your agreement in the doctrines of the Catholic Church; yet because I have also sent letters to all our fellow-ministers in every place with respect to the things which concern Arius and his companions; I have thought it necessary to call together you the clergy of the city, and to summon you also of Mareotis; especially since of your number Chares and Pistus, the priests; Sarapion, Parammon, Zosimus, and Irenaeus, the deacons, have gone over to the party of Arius, and have preferred to be deposed with them; that you may know what is now written, and that you should declare your consent in these matters, and give your suffrage for the deposition of those about Arius and Pistus.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 3:4
verses.text: For it is right that you should know what I have written, and that you should each one, as if he had written it himself retain it in his heart.

chapters.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 4

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 4:1
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 4:2
verses.text: â€”Epistle to aeglon, Bishop of Cynopolis, Against the Arians.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 4:3
verses.text: From a letter of St.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 4:4
verses.text: Alexander, bishop of Alexandria, to aeglon, bishop of Cynopolis, against the Arians.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 4:5
verses.text: Natural will is the free faculty of every intelligent nature as having nothing involuntary which is in respect of its essence.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 4:6
verses.text: Natural operation is the innate motion of all substance.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 4:7
verses.text: Natural operation is the substantial and notifying reason of every nature.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 4:8
verses.text: Natural operation is the notifying virtue of every substance.

chapters.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:1
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:2
verses.text: â€”On the Soul and Body and the Passion of the Lord.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:3
verses.text: The Word which is ungrudgingly sent down from heaven, is fitted for the irrigation of our hearts, if we have been prepared for His power, not by speaking only, but by listening.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:4
verses.text: For as the rain without the ground does not produce fruit, so neither does the Word fructify without hearing, nor hearing without the Word.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:5
verses.text: Moreover, the Word then becomes fruitful when we pronounce it, and in the same way hearing, when we listen.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:6
verses.text: Therefore since the Word draws forth its power, do you also ungrudgingly lend your ears, and when you come to hear, cleanse yourselves from all ill-will and unbelief.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:7
verses.text: Two very bad things are ill-will and unbelief, both of which are contrary to righteousness; for ill-will is opposed to charity, and unbelief to faith; just in the same way as bitterness is opposed to sweetness, darkness to light, evil to good, death to life, falsehood to truth.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:8
verses.text: Those, therefore, who abound in these vices that are repugnant to virtue, are in a manner dead; for the malignant and the unbelieving hate charity and faith, and they who do this are the enemies of God.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:9
verses.text: Since therefore ye know, brethren beloved, that the malignant and the unbelieving are the enemies of righteousness, beware of these, embrace faith and charity, by which all the holy men who have existed from the beginning of the world to this day have attained unto salvation.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:10
verses.text: And show forth the fruit of charity, not in words only, but also in deeds, that is, in all godly patience for God's sake.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:11
verses.text: For, see! the Lord Himself hath shown His charity towards us, not only in words but also in deeds, since He hath given Himself up as the price of our salvation.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:12
verses.text: Besides, we were not created, like the rest of the world, by word alone, but also by deed.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:13
verses.text: For God made the world to exist by the power of a single word, but us He produced by the efficacy alike of His word and working.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:14
verses.text: For it was not enough for God to say, "Let us make man in our image, after our likeness," but deed followed word; for, taking the dust from the ground, He formed man out of it, conformable to His image and similitude, and into him He breathed the breath of life, so that Adam became a living soul.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:15
verses.text: But when man afterwards by his fall had inclined to death, it was necessary that that form should be recreated anew to salvation by the same Artificer.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:16
verses.text: For the form indeed lay rotting in the ground; but that inspiration which had been as the breath of life, was detained separate from the body in a dark place, which is called Hades.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:17
verses.text: There was, therefore, a division of the soul from the body; it was banished ad inferos, whilst the latter was resolved into dust; and there was a great interval of separation between them; for the body, by the dissolution of the flesh, becomes corrupt; the soul being loosened from it, its action ceases.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:18
verses.text: For as when the king is thrown into chains, the city falls to ruin; or as when the general is taken captive, the army is scattered abroad; or as when the helmsman is shaken off, the vessel is submerged; so when the soul is bound in chains, its body goes to pieces; as the city without its king, so its members are dissolved; as is the case with an army when its general is lost, they are drowned in death, even as happens to a vessel when deprived of its helmsman.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:19
verses.text: The soul, therefore, governed the man, as long as the body survived; even as the king governs the city, the general the army, the helmsman the ship.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:20
verses.text: But it was powerless to rule it, from the time when it was immoveably tied to it, and became immersed in error; therefore it was that it declined from the straight path, and followed tempters, giving heed to fornication, idolatry, and shedding of blood; by which evil deeds it has destroyed the proper manhood.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:21
verses.text: Nay, but itself also being carried at length to the lower regions, it was there detained by the wicked tempter.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:22
verses.text: Else was it wont, as the king restores the ruined city, the general collects the dispersed army, the sailor repairs the broken ship, even so, I say, the soul used to minister supplies to the body before that the body was dissolved in the dust, being not as yet itself bound fast with fetters.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:23
verses.text: But after that the soul became bound, not with material fetters but with sins, and thus was rendered impotent to act, then it left its body in the ground, and being cast down to the lower regions, it was made the footstool of death, and despicable to all.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:24
verses.text: Man went forth from paradise to a region which was the sink of unrighteousness, fornication, adultery, and cruel murder.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:25
verses.text: And there he found his destruction; for all things conspired to his death, and worked the ruin of him who had hardly entered there.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:26
verses.text: Meanwhile man wanted some consolation and assistance and rest.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:27
verses.text: For when was it well with man? In his mother's womb? But when he was shut up there, he differed but little from the dead.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:28
verses.text: When he was nourished with milk from the breast? Not even then, indeed, did he feel any joy.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:29
verses.text: Was it rather whilst he was coming to maturity? But then, especially, dangers impended over him from his youthful lusts.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:30
verses.text: Was it, lastly, when he grew old? Nay, but then does he begin to groan, being pressed down by the weight of old age, and the expectation of death.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:31
verses.text: For what else is old age but the expectation of death? Verily all the inhabitants of earth do die, young men and old, little children and adults, for no age or bodily stature is exempt from death.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:32
verses.text: Why, then, is man tormented by this exceeding grief? Doubtless the very aspect of death begets sadness; for we behold in a dead man the face changed, the figure dead, the body shrunk up with emaciation, the mouth silent, the skin cold, the carcase prostrate on the ground, the eyes sunken, the limbs immoveable, the flesh wasted away, the veins congealed, the bones whitened, the joints dissolved, all parts of him reduced to dust, and the man no longer existing.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:33
verses.text: What, then, is man? A flower, I say, that is but for a little time, which in his mother's womb is not apparent, in youth flourishes, but which in old age withers and departs in death.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:34
verses.text: But now, after all this bondage to death and corruption of the manhood, God hath visited His creature, which He formed after His own image and similitude; and this He hath done that it might not for ever be the sport of death.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:35
verses.text: Therefore God sent down from heaven His incorporeal Son to take flesh upon Him in the Virgin's womb; and thus, equally as thou, was He made man; to save lost man, and collect all His scattered members.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:36
verses.text: For Christ, when He joined the manhood to His person, united that which death by the separation of the body had dispersed.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:37
verses.text: Christ suffered that we should live for ever.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:38
verses.text: For else why should Christ have died? Had He committed anything worthy of death? Why did He clothe Himself in flesh who was invested with glory? And since He was God, why did He become man? And since He reigned in heaven, why did He come down to earth, and become incarnate in the virgin's womb? What necessity, I ask, impelled God to come down to earth, to assume flesh, to be wrapped in swaddling clothes in a manger-cradle, to be nourished with the milk from the breast, to receive baptism from a servant, to be lifted up upon the cross, to be interred in an earthly sepulchre, to rise again the third day from the dead? What necessity, I say, impelled Him to this? It is sufficiently discovered that He suffered shame for man's sake, to set him free from death; and that He exclaimed, as in the words of the prophet, "I have endured as a travailing woman".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:39
verses.text: In very deed did He endure for our sakes sorrow, ignominy, torment, even death itself, and burial.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:40
verses.text: For thus He says Himself by the prophet: "I went down into the deep".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:41
verses.text: Who made Him thus to go down? The impious people.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:42
verses.text: Behold, ye sons of men, behold what recompense Israel made unto Him! She slew her Benefactor, returning evil for good, affliction for joy, death for life.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:43
verses.text: They slew by nailing to the tree Him who had brought to life their dead, had healed their maimed, had made their lepers clean, had given light to their blind.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:44
verses.text: Behold, ye sons of men! behold, all ye people, these new wonders! They suspended Him on the tree, who stretches out the earth; they transfixed Him with nails who laid firm the foundation of the world; they circumscribed Him who circumscribed the heavens; they bound Him who absolves sinners; they gave Him vinegar to drink who hath made them to drink of righteousness; they fed Him with gall who hath offered to them the Bread of Life; they caused corruption to come upon His hands, and feet who healed their hands and feet; they violently closed His eyes who restored sight to them; they gave Him over to the tomb, who raised their dead to life both in the time before His Passion and also whilst He was hanging on the tree.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:45
verses.text: For when our Lord was suffering upon the cross, the tombs were burst open, the infernal region was disclosed, the souls leapt forth, the dead returned to life, and many of them were seen in Jerusalem, whilst the mystery of the cross was being perfected; what time our Lord trampled upon death, dissolved the enmity, bound the strong man, and raised the trophy of the cross, His body being lifted up upon it, that the body might appear on high, and death to be depressed under the foot of flesh.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:46
verses.text: Then the heavenly powers wondered, the angels were astonished, the elements trembled, every creature was shaken whilst they looked on this new mystery, and the terrific spectacle which was being enacted in the universe.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:47
verses.text: Yet the entire people, as unconscious of the mystery, exulted over Christ in derision; although the earth was rocking, the mountains, the valleys, and the sea were shaken, and every creature of God was smitten with confusion.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:48
verses.text: The lights of heaven were afraid, the sun fled away, the moon disappeared, the stars withdrew their shining, the day came to end; the angel in astonishment departed from the temple after the rending of the veil, and darkness covered the earth on which its Lord had closed His eyes.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:49
verses.text: Meanwhile hell was with light resplendent, for thither had the star descended.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:50
verses.text: The Lord, indeed, did not descend into hell in His body but in His Spirit.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:51
verses.text: He forsooth is working everywhere, for whilst He raised the dead by His body, by His spirit was He liberating their souls.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:52
verses.text: For when the body of the Lord was hung upon the cross, the tombs, as we have said, were opened; hell was unbarred.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:53
verses.text: the dead received their life, the souls were sent back again into the world, and that because the Lord had conquered hell, had trodden down death, had covered the enemy with shame; therefore was it that the souls came forth from Hades, and the dead appeared upon the earth.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:54
verses.text: Ye see, therefore, how great was the effect of the death of Christ, for no creature endured His fall with equal mind, nor did the elements His Passion, neither did the earth retain His body, nor hell His Spirit.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:55
verses.text: All things were in the Passion of Christ disturbed and convulsed.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:56
verses.text: The Lord exclaimed, as once before to Lazarus, Come forth, ye dead, from your tombs and your secret places; for I, the Christ, give unto you resurrection.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:57
verses.text: For then the earth could not long hold the body of our Lord that in it was buried; but it exclaimed, O my Lord, pardon mine iniquities, save me from Thy wrath, absolve me from the curse, for I have received the blood of the righteous, and yet I have not covered the bodies of men or Thine own body! What is at length this wonderful mystery? Why, O Lord, didst Thou come down to earth, unless it was for man's sake, who has been scattered everywhere: for in every place has Thy fair image been disseminated? Nay! but if thou shouldest give but one little word, at the instant all bodies would stand before Thee.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:58
verses.text: Now, since Thou hast come to earth, and hast sought for the members of Thy fashioning, undertake for man who is Thine own, receive that which is committed to Thee, recover Thine image, Thine Adam.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:59
verses.text: Then the Lord, the third day after His death, rose again, thus bringing man to a knowledge of the Trinity.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:60
verses.text: Then all the nations of the human race were saved by Christ.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:61
verses.text: One submitted to the judgment, and many thousands were absolved.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 5:62
verses.text: Moreover, He being made like to man whom He had saved, ascended to the height of heaven, to offer before His Father, not gold or silver, or precious stones, but the man whom He had formed after His own image and similitude; and the Father, raising Him to His right hand, hath seated Him upon a throne on high, and hath made Him to be judge of the peoples, the leader of the angelic host, the charioteer of the cherubim, the Son of the true Jerusalem, the Virgin's spouse, and King for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:1
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:2
verses.text: â€”The Addition in the Codex, with a Various Reading.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:3
verses.text: God, therefore, wishing to visit His own form which He had fashioned after His own image and similitude, hath in these last times sent into the world His incorporeal and only Son, who being in the Virgin's womb incarnate, was born perfect man to raise erect lost man, re-collecting His scattered members.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:4
verses.text: For why else should Christ have died? Was He capitally accused? And since He was God, why was He made man? Why did He who was reigning in heaven come down to earth? Who compelled God to come down to earth, to take flesh of the holy Virgin, to be wrapped in swaddling clothes and laid in a manger, to be nourished with milk, to be baptized in the Jordan, to be mocked of the people, to be nailed to the tree, to be buried in the bosom of the earth, and the third day to rise again from the dead; in the cause of redemption to give life for life, blood for blood, to undergo death for death? For Christ, by dying, hath discharged the debt of death to which man was obnoxious.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:5
verses.text: Oh, the new and ineffable mystery! the Judge was judged.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:6
verses.text: He who absolves from sin was bound; He was mocked who once framed the world; He was stretched upon the cross who stretched out the heavens; He was fed with gall who gave the manna to be bread; He died who gives life.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:7
verses.text: He was given up to the tomb who raises the dead.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:8
verses.text: The powers were astonished, the angels wondered, the elements trembled, the whole created universe was shaken, the earth quaked, and its foundations rocked; the sun fled away, the elements were subverted, the light of day receded; because they could not bear to look upon their crucified Lord.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:9
verses.text: The creature, in amazement, said, What is this novel mystery? The judge is judged and is silent; the invisible is seen and is not confounded; the incomprehensible is grasped and is not indignant at it; the immeasurable is contained in a measure and makes no opposition; the impassable suffers and does not avenge its own injury; the immortal dies and complains not; the celestial is buried and bears it with an equal mind.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:10
verses.text: What, I say, is this mystery? The creature surely is transfixed with amazement.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:11
verses.text: But when our Lord rose from death and trampled it down, when He bound the strong man and set man free, then every creature wondered at the Judge who for Adam's sake was judged, at the invisible being seen, at the impassable suffering, at the immortal dead, at the celestial buried in the earth.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:12
verses.text: For our Lord was made man; He was condemned that He might impart compassion; He was bound that He might set free; He was apprehended that He might liberate; He suffered that He might heal our sufferings; He died to restore life to us; He was buried to raise us up.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:13
verses.text: For when our Lord suffered, His humanity suffered, that which He had like unto man; and He dissolves the sufferings of him who is His like, and by dying He hath destroyed death.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:14
verses.text: It was for this cause that He came down upon earth, that by pursuing death He might kill the rebel that slew men.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:15
verses.text: For one underwent the judgment, and myriads were set free; one was buried, and myriads rose again.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 6:16
verses.text: He is the Mediator between God and man; He is the resurrection and the salvation of all; He is the Guide of the erring, the Shepherd of men who have been set free, the life of the dead, the charioteer of the cherubim, the standard-bearer of the angels, and the King of kings, to whom be glory for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:1
verses.text: Elucidations.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:2
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:3
verses.text: (Some points, p.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:4
verses.text: )  That the theology of the great school of Alexandria had a character of its own, is most apparent; I should be the last to deny it.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:5
verses.text: As its succession of teachers was like that of hereditary descent in a family, a family likeness is naturally to be found in this school, from the great Clement to the great Athanasius.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:6
verses.text: It is a school that hands on the traditions in which Apollos had been reared; it not less reflects the Greek influences always dominant in the capital of the Macedonian hero; but it is a school in which the Gospel of Christ as the Light of the world was always made predominant: and, while a most liberal view of human knowledge was inculcated in it, yet the faith was always exalted as the mother and mistress of the true gnosis and of all science.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:7
verses.text: The wise men of this world were summoned with an imperial voice, from this eldest seat and centre of Christian learning, to cast their crowns and their treasures at the feet of Jesus.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:8
verses.text: With a generous patronage Clement conceded all he could to the philosophy of the Greeks, and yet sublimely rose above it to a sphere it never discovered, and looked down upon all merely human intellect and its achievements like Uriel in the sun.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:9
verses.text: It was the special though unconscious mission of this school to prepare the way, and to shape the thought of Christendom, for the great epoch of the (nominal) conversion of the empire, and for the all-important synodical period, its logical consequence.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:10
verses.text: It was in this school that the technical formulas of the Church were naturally wrought out.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:11
verses.text: The process was like that of the artist who has first to make his own tools.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:12
verses.text: He does many things, and resorts to many contrivances, never afterwards necessary when once the tools are complete and his laboratory furnished with all he wants for his work.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:13
verses.text: To my mind, therefore, it is but a pastime of no practical worth to contrast the idiosyncrasies of Clement with those of Origen, and to set up distinctions between the Logos of this doctor and that.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:14
verses.text: The differences to be descried belong to the personal peculiarities of great minds not yet guided to unity of diction by a scientific theology.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:15
verses.text: The marvel is their harmony of thought.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:16
verses.text: Their ends and their antagonisms are the same.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:17
verses.text: The outcome of their mental efforts and their pious faith is seen in the result.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:18
verses.text: Alexander was their product, and Athanasius (bringing all their sheaves to the Church's garner, winnowed and harvested) is the perpetual gnomon of the Alexandrian school.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:19
verses.text: Its testimony, its prescription, its harmony and unity, are all summed up in him.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:20
verses.text: It is extraordinary that many truly evangelical critics seem to see, in the subordination taught by Origen, something not reconcileable with the Nicene orthodoxy.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:21
verses.text: Even Bishop Bull is a subordinationist, and so are all the great orthodox divines.

Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:26
verses.text: )  As so shortly preceding the meeting of the Great Council, this letter is most important as a clear testimony to the meaning the first council attached to that article of the Creed which affirms "one holy Catholic and Apostolic Church".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:27
verses.text: We must compare the Treatises of Cyprian for the West, with this and the Letter of Firmilian for the East, as clearly elucidating the contemporary mind of the Church, and hence the meaning of those words which reflect their mind in the Creed.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:28
verses.text: To make any reflections of my own would be out of place, save only, negatively, as I compare it with the modern creed of the Council of Trent (Pius IV.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:29
verses.text: ), which defines the Catholic Church to be the communion which acknowledges the Church of Rome as "the mother and mistress of churches".

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:30
verses.text: The concluding section of this letter is decisive as to the absolute autonomy of the Alexandrian dioecese.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:31
verses.text: To all the other churches Alexander merely communicates his sentence, which they are all bound to respect.

verses.name: Alexander of Alexandria: On the Arian Heresy 7:32
verses.text: Whether the Christian Church at this period reflected the Apostolic Institutions is not the question, but merely what its theory was in the fourth century, and how far East and West accorded with the theory of Cyprian.
